title: 108_hr2070
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare+Choice Revitalization Act of 2003" and includes improvements to Medicare+Choice. The Medicare+Choice Revitalization Act of 2003 includes provisions for equalizing payments between fee-for-service and Medicare+Choice based on 100 percent of fee-for-service costs. The Medicare+Choice Revitalization Act of 2003 aims to equalize payments between fee-for-service and Medicare+Choice plans by adjusting the average per capita cost to include additional payments for services from VA and DoD facilities. The Medicare+Choice Revitalization Act of 2003 is amended to include payments for services from VA and DoD facilities, with revisions to the national average used in calculations and changes in budget neutrality. The Medicare+Choice Revitalization Act of 2003 includes revisions to minimum percentage increase in capitation rates and the inclusion of costs of DOD and VA military facility services in Medicare+Choice calculations. The Medicare+Choice Revitalization Act of 2003 includes amendments to include costs of DOD and VA military facility services in Medicare+Choice payment rates for Medicare-eligible beneficiaries. The Medicare+Choice Revitalization Act of 2003 includes amendments to factor in costs of DOD and VA military facility services in Medicare+Choice payment rates for Medicare-eligible beneficiaries. The Secretary will announce revised Medicare+Choice capitation rates for 2004 within 4 weeks of the Act's enactment. Additionally, the MedPAC will conduct a study on the method used for determining the adjusted average per capita cost (AAPCC). The Medicare+Choice Revitalization Act of 2003 includes amendments to factor in costs of DOD and VA military facility services in Medicare+Choice payment rates for Medicare-eligible beneficiaries. The MedPAC will conduct a study on the adjusted average per capita cost (AAPCC) under the Social Security Act, examining variation in costs between different areas and the accuracy of risk adjustment methods. A report on the study will be submitted to Congress within 9 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a report to Congress by July 1, 2004, detailing the impact of increased financial assistance on Medicare+Choice plans in various areas, including the effects on premiums and benefits. SEC. 3. MAKING PERMANENT CHANGE IN MEDICARE+CHOICE REPORTING DEADLINES AND ANNUAL, COORDINATED ELECTION PERIOD. The text chunk discusses amendments to reporting deadlines and election periods in the Social Security Act related to Medicare+Choice. The changes include altering reporting deadlines for payment rates and the annual, coordinated election period. Amendments to reporting deadlines and election periods in the Social Security Act related to Medicare+Choice, including changes to reporting deadlines for payment rates and the annual, coordinated election period. The first sentence of section 1851(d)(2)(A)(ii) of the Act is amended to require the provision of available information comparing plan options. SEC. 4. AVOIDING DUPLICATIVE STATE REGULATION. Amends Section 1856(b)(3) of the Social Security Act to supersede State laws or regulations for Medicare+Choice plans, except for licensing and solvency laws. Effective upon enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. SPECIALIZED MEDICARE+CHOICE PLANS FOR SPECIAL NEEDS BENEFICIARIES. Specialized Medicare+Choice plans for special needs beneficiaries may be any type of coordinated care plan. This plan exclusively serves special needs beneficiaries as defined in the Act. Special needs beneficiaries for Specialized Medicare+Choice plans are defined as individuals who are institutionalized, entitled to medical assistance under a State plan, residing in a Continuing Care Retirement Community, or meet specific requirements determined by the Secretary. The Medicare+Choice plan can restrict enrollment for individuals with special needs beneficiaries, as defined in subsection (b)(4), before January 1, 2007. The Medicare Benefits Administrator must submit a report to Congress by December 31, 2006. The Medicare Benefits Administrator will submit a report to Congress assessing the impact of specialized Medicare+Choice plans for special needs beneficiaries on cost and quality of services. The amendments made by subsections (a), (b), and (c) will take effect upon the enactment of this Act, with final regulations for special needs beneficiaries to be issued within 6 months. 1859(b)(4)(B)(iii) of the Social Security Act, added by subsection (b), will be implemented.
